answers.answer: I have never heard of static migraine. My advise would be to seek out the best neuroophthalmologist that is within 4-5 hours driving and get your tests together and get over to him/her for a second opinion. you can find one near your at www.aao.org    OR you may want to go to one affiliated with a University department of ophthalmology.JCH MD

question: I'm a 37 year old female who was diagnosed diabetic close to 20 years ago. Diabetes runs through my family history on maternal & paternal sides.  I come from a family with 6 biological siblings and as it stands, 5 out of the 6 have also been diagnosed as diabetic.  I'm in great shape and have always taken care of myself.  My BMI has always been around 19.  (5'4" and +/- 110lbs)  Though my A1C has always stayed below 7, I have had eye troubles since my early twenties.  A scotoma in  my left eye is actually what led me to the eye doctor and eventually was diagnosed with diabetes.  Before my diabetes diagnosis, my neurologist ordered a MRI and diagnosed my eye scotoma as a static migraine.  Meanwhile, 15 years later, I now have 6 scotomas in one eye and 8 in the other.  I also experience flashes of light in the dark and during the day every time I blink.   When I cover one eye, 3/4 of my vision in the other eye seems to disappear and reappear almost rythmic behind a black "sheet". Lately, I have been extremely fatigued (more than usual) and experience blurry/double vision and pain behind both eyes upon moving them left/right up/down.  On some days my scotomas are dark grey and become blind spots instead of transluscent.  Symptoms are stronger on some days more than others.  After my MRI, I should mention that the radiologists report suggested that I had a MS plaque visible on my frontal lobe, but the neurologist declined to concur at the time. He believed that my symptoms were indicative of a ocular migraine.  I have summed up over the years that I need to live with the "static migraine" dx.  As of recently a huge scotoma twice as large as others appeared right in my line of vision and made driving almost impossible.  It has since faded to appear as the others.  Now, post MRI 15+ years, eye symptoms continue to darken and then lighten, but are alway present.  Last week I saw my Opthalmologist and had a complete dilated eye exam...completely within normal limits as usual... No diabetic changes at all.  I have a MRI scheduled next week to look for progression/changes of said "MS plaque", just in case.  What do these symptoms bring to mind, if my MRI is within normal limits, or no change, what do you believe my next step should be?
title: Help with Symptoms ... What Next?
